Mrs. Fields Cookies and Hershey Foods Corporation each agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that their websites violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act by collecting personal information from children without first obtaining the proper parental consent.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Mylan and UpJohn merged to form Viatris in 2020
Description: The Federal Trade Commission approved a $100 million settlement with Mylan Laboratories, Inc. resolving allegations that four companies, including Mylan, conspired to deny Mylan's competitors ingredients necessary to manufacture two widely-prescribed anti-anxiety drugs.

The Nahdree Group, Ltd. -- a New York-based manufacturer of women's evening and special occasion wear -- agreed to pay a $10,000 civil penalty to settle allegations that it violated the Federal Trade Commission's Care Labeling Rule by using labels stating Dryclean Only by Zurcion Method.

The Federal Trade Commission won a $10.2 million judgment against debt- collection company National Check Control and its principals for violations of the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act. In addition, a federal district court judge permanently banned the defendants from engaging in debt collection in the future.

A suburban Chicago-area telemarketing company charged with sending unordered merchandise to small businesses around the country and then billing them for it agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission and State of Illinois charges that it was violating federal law. The settlement barred National Maintenance Supply, Inc. and its owner from any future telemarketing of office, cleaning or janitorial supplies and required payment of $80,000 in consumer redress.

Following a public comment period, the Federal Trade Commission approved a final consent order with a company that deceptively advertised its add-on biweekly auto payment plan. National Payment Network, Inc. is required to issue $1.5 million in consumer refunds within 30 days of service of the order, and will waive another $949,000 in fees to current customers.

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2017 Carlyle Group sold NBTY to KKR, which sold it to Nestle in 2021
Description: The Federal Trade Commission reached a settlement requiring major marketers of children's vitamins to stop making false and unproven claims that their supplements promote healthy brain and eye development in children. The companies agreed to pay $2.1 million to provide refunds to consumers who purchased certain multivitamins in their Disney and Marvel Heroes line.

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2010 NBTY was acquired by Carlyle Group, which sold it in 2017 to KKR, which sold it in 2021 to Nestle
Description: NBTY Inc., a leading manufacturer and distributor of dietary supplements in the United States and abroad, agreed to pay a $2 million civil penalty to settle allegations that it violated the terms of a 1995 FTC order by making false and misleading health claims about two of its products.

Recap of Ownership Changes: NCO, which later changed its name to Expert Global Solutions, was bought by Alorica in 2016
Description: One of the nation's largest debt-collection firms was required to pay $1.5 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it violated the Fair Credit Reporting Act by reporting inaccurate information about consumer accounts to credit bureaus.

The marketer of a device advertised as a less expensive alternative to the PC for Internet access and e-mail agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that its sales and billing practices violated federal laws.

A company and its owner were ordered to return $160,000 to consumers and were banned for life from promoting or selling franchises or business opportunities after the Federal Trade Commission charged that they used bogus earnings claims to lure franchisees into buying their web services businesses, and failed to tell customers that the owner was under a previous FTC order for deceptively promoting rare coins.

Two authorized dealers of the satellite television provider Dish Network agreed to settle charges that they violated the FTC's Telemarketing Sales Rule by calling consumers whose numbers are on the Do Not Call Registry.

Company: New World Auto Imports Inc., New World Auto Imports of Rockwall Inc. and Hampton Two Auto Corporation

Description: Three list management companies agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they violated the Telemarketing Sales Rule.

Nine West Group Inc., a large supplier of women's shoes, agreed to settle charges that it engaged in resale price fixing with certain dealers in violation of federal and state antitrust laws. Nine West entered into separate settlements with the Federal Trade Commission and the Attorneys General for 56 U.S. states, territories, commonwealths, and possessions. The FTC's order prevented Nine West from engaging in these illegal practices in the future. In addition, Nine West's settlement with the Attorneys General required it to pay $34 million.

The Federal Trade Commission announced complaints and proposed court orders barring four national retailers from mislabeling and advertising rayon textiles as made of bamboo, and requiring them to pay civil penalties totaling $1.3 million.

Following a public comment period, the Federal Trade Commission has approved two final orders settling charges that two companies, Norm Thompson Outfitters. Inc., and Wacoal America, Inc., misled consumers regarding the ability of their caffeine-infused shapewear undergarments to reshape the wearer's body and reduce cellulite.

North American Capital Corporation agreed to pay a $250,000 civil penalty as part of a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission to resolve allegations that it violated the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act when attempting to collect delinquent consumer credit accounts.

Company: North American Herb & Spice Co., LLC
Description: The marketers of a line of dietary supplements agreed to pay $2.5 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that claims about their oregano oil and capsules were false and unsubstantiated in violation of federal law.

An Illinois company and its owner agreed to stop making allegedly deceptive claims that their dietary supplements are proven effective at treating childhood speech disorders, including those associated with autism, in order to settle Federal Trade Commission charges. Under the FTC settlement, the defendants also had to pay $200,000 and disclose any material connections with their endorsers.

Nu West, Inc., a Bellevue, Washington-based lender, and its owner agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they violated the Home Ownership and Equity Protection Act, the Truth in Lending Act, and the FTC Act when making high-cost loans to consumers that were secured by their homes.

Company: NutriMost, LLC and NutriMost Doctors, LLC
Description: The marketers of a weight-loss system advertised as using "breakthrough technology" and "personalized supplements" to help consumers permanently lose "20 to 40+ pounds in 40 days" without significantly cutting calories, agreed to settle a Federal Trade Commission complaint that the claims were deceptive and not supported by scientific evidence.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Techtronic acquired the bankrupt Oreck in 2013.
Description: The Federal Trade Commission finalized the Order settling charges that Oreck Corporation made false and unproven claims that two of its appliances can reduce the risk of flu and other illnesses, and eliminate virtually all common germs and allergens. The company also agreed to pay $750,000.

Company: The Original Honey Baked Ham Co. of Georgia Inc.
Description: Seven large Internet e-tailers agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they violated the Mail and Telephone Order Rule during the 1999 holiday shopping season by providing buyers inadequate notice of shipping delays or continuing to promise specific delivery dates when timely fulfillment was impossible.

Company: Partners in Health Care Association Inc.
Description: The FTC announced that what it called a health care scammer and his company, who tricked Spanish-speaking and other consumers seeking health insurance into buying phony medical discount cards, were banned from selling healthcare-related products, and from telemarketing, under court orders obtained by the Commission.

The operator of the Path social networking app has agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it deceived users by collecting personal information from their mobile device address books without their knowledge and consent. The settlement required Path, Inc. to establish a comprehensive privacy program and to obtain independent privacy assessments every other year for the next 20 years. The company also had to pay $800,000 to settle charges that it illegally collected personal information from children without their parents consent.

Seven large Internet e-tailers agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they violated the Mail and Telephone Order Rule during the 1999 holiday shopping season by providing buyers inadequate notice of shipping delays or continuing to promise specific delivery dates when timely fulfillment was impossible.

A U.S. District Court ordered the operators of several international tech support scams to pay more than $5.1 million, acting on Federal Trade Commission charges that they masqueraded as major computer companies, tricked consumers into believing their computers were riddled with malware and then charged consumers to fix them.

A U.S. District Court ordered the operators of several international tech support scams to pay more than $5.1 million, acting on Federal Trade Commission charges that they masqueraded as major computer companies, tricked consumers into believing their computers were riddled with malware and then charged consumers to fix them.

Pelle Pelle, Inc., a Michigan-based clothing importer, agreed to pay a $40,000 civil penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it put improper care labels on several styles of men's pants and jackets.

PeoplePC, Inc., a San Francisco, California-based seller of personal computers, computer peripherals, software, and Internet service, agreed to pay a $100,000 civil penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it failed to tell thousands of consumers in advance that their deliveries would be delayed, provide them with an opportunity to cancel or consent to the delay, or send them cancellation refunds within the time-frame required.

Generic drug manufacturers Alpharma Inc. and Perrigo Company agreed to give up a total of $6.25 million in illegal profits to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that their agreement to limit competition for over-the-counter store-brand children's liquid ibuprofen drove up prices and violated federal law.

Two Maine-based dietary supplement marketers and their principals have agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they made deceptive advertising claims about their dietary supplement products, in violation of federal law.

The operators of 20 online virtual worlds agreed to pay $3 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule by illegally collecting and disclosing personal information from hundreds of thousands of children under age 13 without their parents' prior consent.

Company: PLS Financial Services, Inc. and The Payday Loan Store of Illinois, Inc.
Description: A company that provides management services to more than 300 payday loan and check cashing stores, and an affiliated company that owns and operates several stores, will pay $101,500 to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they violated federal law by allowing sensitive consumer information to be tossed into trash dumpsters.

Company: Polling Associates Inc. and Boomerang International, LLC
Description: A series of defendants agreed to pay approximately $10 million to the Federal Trade Commission to settle charges that they operated a massive scam that sent unwanted text messages to millions of consumers, many of whom later received illegal robocalls, phony free merchandise offers, and unauthorized charges crammed on their mobile phone bills.

Company: Premier Precious Metals Inc., Rushmore Consulting Group Inc., and PPM Credit Inc.
Description: The operator of a bogus precious metals investment scheme that bilked millions of dollars from investors, including many senior citizens, was permanently banned from selling any investment opportunities under a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission.

Company: Pure Health LLC and Genesis Today Inc.
Description: Lindsey Duncan and the companies he controlled agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they deceptively touted the supposed weight-loss benefits of green coffee bean extract through a campaign that included appearances on The Dr. Oz Show, The View, and other television programs. Under the FTC settlement, the defendants were barred from making deceptive claims about the health benefits or efficacy of any dietary supplement or drug product, and had to pay $9 million for consumer redress.

Two companies that fired workers and rejected job applicants based on background checks without informing them of their rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they violated federal law.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Liberty Interactive changed its name to Qurate Retail in 2018.
Description: QVC, Inc., a TV home shopping channel, agreed to pay $7.5 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it made false and unsubstantiated claims about three types of dietary supplements in violation of an FTC order, and about an anti-cellulite skin cream in violation of the FTC Act.

Two companies that fired workers and rejected job applicants based on background checks without informing them of their rights under the Fair Credit Reporting Act agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they violated federal law.

A West Virginia auto dealer, Ramey Motors Inc., agreed to pay a $80,000 civil penalty to settle a Federal Trade Commission lawsuit brought in 2014. The FTC charged Ramey Motors with violating the terms of a 2012 consent order with the FTC that barred it from deceptively advertising the cost of buying or leasing cars.

A federal judge ruled in favor of the Federal Trade Commission and ordered Real Wealth, Inc. and its owner, Lance Murkin, to pay $10.4 million, the full amount of harm caused to thousands of consumers nationwide who were victimized by the Defendants' work-at-home and grant scams. The Court also banned Real Wealth and Murkin from marketing or selling work-at-home or grant-related products, and from assisting others in doing so.

Two payday lenders settled Federal Trade Commission charges that they illegally charged consumers across the country undisclosed and inflated fees. The two companies, Red Cedar Services Inc. and SFS Inc., each paid $2.2 million and collectively waived $68 million in fees to consumers that were not collected.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Authentic acquired Reebok in 2022
Description: Reebok International Ltd. agreed to resolve charges that the company deceptively advertised "toning shoes," which it claimed would provide extra tone and strength to leg and buttock muscles. Reebok will pay $25 million as part of the settlement agreement. The funds will be made available for consumer refunds either directly from the FTC or through a court-approved class action lawsuit.

A Memphis-based debt collector agreed to stop deceiving and harassing consumers and otherwise violating federal debt collection laws, and will pay a $1.5 million civil penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission charges, while a debt collection operation headquartered outside New York City will pay $490,000 as a penalty to settle a separate FTC complaint.

Two app developers agreed to pay a combined $360,000 in civil penalties as part of settlements with the Federal Trade Commission over charges they violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act.

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2010 NBTY was acquired by Carlyle Group, which sold it in 2017 to KKR, which sold it in 2021 to Nestle
Description: Rexall Sundown, Inc. agreed to pay up to $12 million in consumer redress to resolve Federal Trade Commission allegations that it made misleading claims while marketing a dietary supplement.

The Federal Trade Commission announced a settlement with RHI AG to resolve allegations that it violated provisions of an FTC order issued in 2001 requiring the company to conduct asbestos remediation at a divested plant.

National pharmacy chain Rite Aid Corporation agreed to pay $500,000 to settle FTC charges that it deceptively advertised that its Germ Defense tablets and lozenges could prevent and treat colds and the flu or reduce the severity and duration of these illnesses.

A Texas-based company owned and operated by a husband and wife team has agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it violated federal law by lying to consumer reporting agencies, often referred to as credit bureaus, and charging consumers up-front fees before providing its services. The court order settling the FTC's complaint for civil penalties, which was filed by the U.S. Department of Justice, bars the defendants from similar conduct in the future, imposes a $2.35 million civil penalty, and requires them to pay $400,000.

Company: Rose Creek Health Products, Inc. and The Staff of Life, Inc.
Description: Two Washington-based companies and the individual who controlled them agreed to pay $375,000 in redress to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they made false and unsubstantiated health claims in their advertising for a purported nutritional supplement called Vitamin O.

Three Internet marketers of cosmetic, "circle" contact lenses agreed to resolve Federal Trade Commission charges by entering into settlements that will put a stop to their alleged illegal practice of selling lenses to consumers without prescriptions.

Company: RTB Enterprises, Inc. dba Allied Data Corporation
Description: A Houston debt collection company, RTB Enterprises, Inc., which does business as Allied Data Corporation, and Raymond T. Blair, its president and sole shareholder, have agreed to a federal court order prohibiting them from the allegedly deceptive tactics they have been using to pressure English and Spanish-speaking consumers into paying debts and unnecessary fees.

Sage Automotive Group agreed to pay more than $3.6 million to consumers in order to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it used deceptive and unfair sales and financing practices, deceptive advertising, and deceptive online reviews.

A Glendale, California-based operation known as Sale Slash will stop using spam emails and fake news websites with phony celebrity endorsements and unsupported efficacy claims to promote its supposed weight-loss products. The court order resolving the FTC's charges will result in Sale Slash LLC and five other defendants turning over assets that, combined with those already secured by a court-appointed receiver, total approximately $10 million, the bulk of which will be returned to consumers who bought the bogus supplements.

Marketers of the BodyFlex+ System agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they deceptively advertised that BodyFlex caused users to lose from four to 14 inches in the first seven days. The settlement established a $2.6 million consumer refund program.

New York-based Scholastic Inc. and two of its subsidiaries, Scholastic-at-Home and Grolier Incorporated, agreed to settle allegations that they violated laws enforced by the FTC in marketing their negative option book clubs.

Amazon.com, Inc.; Leon Max, Inc.; Macy's, Inc.; and Sears, Roebuck and Co. and its Kmart subsidiaries, Kmart Corporation and Kmart.com, agreed to pay penalties totaling $1.26 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they violated the Textile Products Identification Act (Textile Act) and the FTC's Textile Rules by labeling and advertising products sold in stores and online as made of bamboo, while they actually were made of rayon.

Company: Seasilver USA, Inc. and Americaloe, Inc.
Description: Two California-based companies that promoted the dietary supplement Seasilver with allegedly false medical claims were banned from making false or unsubstantiated claims for any dietary supplement, food, drug, or device as part of a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission. They also agreed to pay a total of $4.5 million in consumer redress.

Company: Security Credit Services, LLC, and Jacob Law Group, PLLC
Description: After allegedly misleading consumers into paying unnecessary fees and falsely threatening consumers with lawsuits, defendants in a debt collection operation agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges.
Two Internet marketers of non-corrective, cosmetic contact lenses agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they violated federal law by selling lenses without a prescription.

Two payday lenders settled Federal Trade Commission charges that they illegally charged consumers across the country undisclosed and inflated fees. The two companies, Red Cedar Services Inc. and SFS Inc., each paid $2.2 million and collectively waived $68 million in fees to consumers that were not collected.

At the request of the Federal Trade Commission, a federal judge ordered Sili Neutraceuticals LLC to pay more than $2.5 million for making false advertising claims and sending illegal e-mail messages in violation of the FTC Act and the CAN-SPAM Act (Controlling the Assault of Non-Solicited Pornography and Marketing Act).

A group of defendants settled Federal Trade Commission charges that they knowingly provided scammers with hundreds of thousands of consumers' sensitive personal information, including Social Security and bank account numbers.

The Federal Trade Commission announced that Skechers USA, Inc. agreed to pay $40 million to settle charges that the company deceived consumers by making unfounded claims that Shape-ups would help people lose weight, and strengthen and tone their buttocks, legs and abdominal muscles.

SmartClick Media LLC, also doing business as Doctor Trusted, and its owner Robert Vozdecky, also known as Bill Anderson, agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that their Doctor Trusted certification program misled consumers with bogus claims that the products sold on websites with its seal were evaluated by doctors using their medical expertise.

Company: Solace International, Inc. and Bioscience Research Institute LLC
Description: Two companies that market skin care and weight-loss products agreed to stop making false or unsubstantiated deceptive claims about their products, under settlements resolving charges in two separate cases brought by the Federal Trade Commission.

Sony BMG Music Entertainment agreed to pay $1 million as part of a settlement to resolve Federal Trade Commission allegations that it violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act through its music fan websites.

On behalf of the Federal Trade Commission, the Department of Justice filed a complaint and consent decree against Alabama-based Oxmoor House and its parent Southern Progress Corporation, a magazine corporation also based in Alabama. As part of the consent decree, the companies agreed to pay $500,000 in civil penalties to resolve allegations charges that they did not adequately inform consumers about the terms of their free trial book offers.

Spokeo, Inc., a data broker that compiles and sells detailed information profiles on millions of consumers, agreed to pay $800,000 to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it marketed the profiles to companies in the human resources, background screening, and recruiting industries without taking steps to protect consumers required under the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2020 Sprint merged with T-Mobile US.
Description: Mobile service provider Sprint agreed to pay $2.95 million in civil penalties to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that the company failed to give proper notice to consumers who were placed in a program for customers with lower credit scores and charged an extra monthly fee.

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2013 Sprint was acquired by SoftBank. In 2020 it merged with T-Mobile US.
Description: Sprint Corporation and AT&T Corp. agreed to pay $1.125 million and $365,000, respectively, to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they failed to notify certain applicants for telephone service of their rights under federal credit laws.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Sycamore bought Staples in 2017
Description: The Federal Trade Commission settled a complaint accusing office superstore Staples, Inc. with misleading customers on its website about the "real time" availability of its products and its ability to deliver purchases in the time promised.

Star Credit Services Inc. of Holbrook, New York, and its owner were permanently enjoined from deceptively offering or selling advance-fee loans as a result of a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission. The settlement required payment of $120,000 for consumer redress.

Star Pipe Products, Ltd., a supplier of ductile iron pipe fittings, agreed to pay $120,000 in civil penalties to resolve Federal Trade Commission allegations that it violated a 2012 Commission order prohibiting it from sharing competitively sensitive information. It also agreed to an order modification that adds training and notification obligations to prevent future violations.

Star Publishing Group, Inc., doing business as National Consumer Services, and its president agreed to pay $100,000 in redress to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they used deceptive and illegal practices in marketing a work-at-home employment guide on how to start a business as an HUD/FHA mortgage insurance refund tracer.

Stewart Finance Company, seven related companies, and their principals agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that the companies deceived consumers, many of them elderly, by, among other things, packing optional products such as accidental death and dismemberment insurance and membership in roadside assistance clubs onto small personal loans of $500 or less. The settlement required the companies to shut down and to agree to the entry of a $10.5 million judgment.
Stratford Career Institute agreed to stop making allegedly deceptive claims about educational programs under a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission.

Company: Sunny Health Nutrition Technology & Products, Inc.
Description: Sunny Health Nutrition was ordered to pay the $1.6 million balance of a 2006 false advertising settlement after the FTC learned that the company had $1.8 million in an account that was not disclosed at the time the agency agreed to accept a reduced penalty because of the defendant's supposed inability to pay the full amount.

At the request of the Federal Trade Commission, a federal court ordered Swish Marketing, Inc. to pay more than $4.8 million for tricking hundreds of thousands of payday loan applicants into paying for an unrelated debit card.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Deutsche Telekom ceased to be a majority owner after T-Mobile merged with Sprint in 2020
Description: T-Mobile agreed to fully refund its customers for unwanted third-party charges it placed on their phone bills, a practice known as mobile cramming, paying at least $90 million to settle a Federal Trade Commission lawsuit.

Three Florida-based affiliate marketers charged with using illegal spam e-mail, false weight-loss claims, and phony celebrity endorsements to market bogus weight-loss products agreed to pay $500,000 to settle with the Federal Trade Commission.

The Federal Trade Commission announced a settlement with Tactica International Inc. under which the New York City-based company was required to pay a $300,000 civil penalty for allegedly failing to live up to its shipment promises for a wide range of products, including the Epil-Stop hair-removal system.

TALX Corporation, a subsidiary of Equifax Inc., agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it violated federal law by failing to provide certain disclosures to users of their consumer reports and to entities that provide information for consumer reports.

The Federal Trade Commission reached a settlement with a Virginia company of numerous allegations of false and unsubstantiated claims concerning weight-loss products, pain-relief magnets, air cleaners, and hair-growth stimulants.

Two New York-based companies that marketed devices that purported to block harmful radiation from cell phones or video display units agreed to pay $85,000 for consumer redress to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that the companies's claims were false and unsubstantiated.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Fiserv bought First Data in 2019
Description: TeleCheck Services, Inc., one of the nation's largest check authorization service companies, along with its associated debt-collection entity, TRS Recovery Services, Inc., agreed to pay $3.5 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they violated the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

A group of companies settled allegations that they deceived and charged improper fees to approximately 25,000 consumers who misdialed while trying to call the popular television show American Idol to vote for their favorite performer during the 2002 and 2003 seasons.
Teletrack, Inc. agreed to pay $1.8 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it sold credit reports to marketers, in violation of the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

Company: Thermalkool, Thermalcool, and Energy Conservation Specialists
Description: A federal court ordered a home insulation marketer to pay a $350,000 civil penalty for making deceptive and unsubstantiated claims about his products' insulation capabilities. On the Federal Trade Commission's behalf, the U.S. Department of Justice won the order on the merits of the case without a trial. The $350,000 figure is the largest civil penalty awarded in a home insulation case.

Online resale ticket exchange TicketNetwork, Inc., and two of its marketing partners, Ryadd, Inc. and SecureBoxOffice, LLC, have settled Federal Trade Commission and State of Connecticut allegations that their advertisements and websites misled consumers into thinking they were buying event tickets from the original venue at face value. Instead, the complaint alleges, the defendants' websites actually were ticket reseller sites with event tickets often priced above the venue's original price.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Charter bought Time Warner Cable in 2016
Description: Time Warner Cable, Inc. has agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that the company violated the Risk-Based Pricing Rule, which requires creditors to give notice to consumers who are provided less favorable credit terms based on information in their credit reports.

Online review site Yelp, Inc., and mobile app developer TinyCo, Inc., agreed to settle separate Federal Trade Commission charges that they improperly collected children's information in violation of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, or COPPA, Rule. Under the terms of the settlements, Yelp will pay a $450,000 civil penalty, while TinyCo will pay a $300,000 civil penalty.

An Internet marketer of adult entertainment was required to pay a $465,000 civil penalty under a settlement reached with the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice, which charged the company with initiating sexually explicit commercial e-mails.

Athletic apparel company Tommie Copper, Inc. and its founder agreed to pay $1.35 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they deceptively advertised the company's copper-infused compression clothing would relieve severe and chronic pain and inflammation caused by arthritis and other diseases.

Toys R Us, Inc.  agreed to pay a $1.3 million civil penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it violated a 1998 order governing its dealings with its suppliers. The order prohibited Toys R Us from urging any supplier to limit supply of products or refuse to sell to discounters.

Seven large Internet e-tailers agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they violated the Mail and Telephone Order Rule during the 1999 holiday shopping season by providing buyers inadequate notice of shipping delays or continuing to promise specific delivery dates when timely fulfillment was impossible.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Verizon acquired Tracfone in 2021
Description: TracFone, the largest prepaid mobile provider in the U.S., agreed to pay $40 million to the Federal Trade Commission to settle charges that it deceived millions of consumers with hollow promises of unlimited data service.

Three national consumer reporting agencies agreed to a total of $2.5 million in payments as part of settlements of allegations that they each violated provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act by failing to maintain a toll-free telephone number with personnel accessible to consumers during normal business hours.

A company and its owner were banned from selling weight-loss patches and fined $180,000 to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that advertising claims for their weight-loss patches were false and unsubstantiated.

Company: Triad Discount Buying Service Inc. et al.
Description: A group of buying clubs including Triad Discount Buying Service Inc., a Boca Raton-based business, its related companies and their operator agreed to pay more than $9 million to settle allegations by the Federal Trade Commission and state Attorneys General that they misled consumers into accepting trial club memberships and obtained billing information from telemarketers without the consumers' knowledge or authorization.

The loan-servicing arm of Texas-based auto dealer Tricolor Auto Group agreed to pay $82,777 in civil penalties as part of a settlement to address Federal Trade Commission charges that it failed to have written policies and procedures regarding the accuracy of reported credit information, and failed to properly investigate disputed consumer credit information.

The marketers of a cactus-based fruit drink agreed to provide $3.5 million for consumer refunds in order to settle FTC charges that they deceived consumers with unsupported claims that their drink, Nopalea, would treat a variety of health problems.

Turnkey Vending, Inc. and its principals agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they failed to provide the pre-sale disclosure documents required by the FTC's Franchise Rule to prospective purchasers of their various vending machine business opportunities.

Uber Technologies agreed to pay $20 million to resolve Federal Trade Commission allegations that it misled prospective drivers with exaggerated earning claims and claims about financing through its Vehicle Solutions Program.

Company: Ultra Ribbons, Inc. and Allstate Imaging, Inc.
Description: Ultra Ribbons, Inc., Allstate Imaging, Inc. and their principals agreed to pay a $500,000 civil penalty and consumer redress to resolve FTC allegations that they engaged in an office-supplies scam.

UMG Recordings, Inc. and Bonzi Software, Inc. each agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act by knowingly collecting personal information from children online without first obtaining parental consent.

Company: United Fitness of America, LLC et al.
Description: United Fitness of America, LLC; eBrands Commerce Group, LLC; Tristar Products, Inc.; and their principals agreed to pay more than $5 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that their Fast Abs belt did not produce "six pack" abs without exercise as they advertised.
In three separate recent actions, the Federal Trade Commission settled allegations against companies engaged in the deceptive sale of "equal employment opportunity" advertisements.
United Payphones of America, Inc., which was targeted by the Federal Trade Commission as part of a nationwide crackdown on fraudulent business opportunities, agreed to pay a $22,000 civil penalty.

Houston, Texas-based United Recovery Systems, Inc. agreed to pay a $240,000 civil penalty as part of a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission to resolve allegations that the company violated the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act.

Univend, LLC and its owner agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they failed to provide the pre-sale disclosure documents required by the FTC's Franchise Rule to prospective purchasers of their vending machine business opportunities.

Company: Universal Appliances, Kitchens, and Baths, Inc.
Description: An online appliance retailer agreed to pay a $100,000 penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it failed to post required EnergyGuide information on its websites to inform consumers about the energy use of major home appliances it sold.

Universal Processing Services of Wisconsin, LLC, a payment processor, and telemarketer Hal E. Smith and his company HES Merchant Services Company, Inc., defendants in the Federal Trade Commission's case against a deceptive robocall credit card interest rate reduction scheme, were jointly ordered to pay $1,734,972 to the Commission by a Florida district court. The money was to be used to provide refunds to defrauded consumers.
Online advertiser ValueClick, Inc. agreed to pay $2.9 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that its advertising claims and e-mails were deceptive and violated federal law.

ValueVision International, Inc., a home shopping retailer, agreed to pay a $215,000 civil penalty to resolve allegations that it violated a previous Federal Trade Commission order by making unsubstantiated health claims for Physician's RX, a dietary supplement.

Company: Vending Communications, Inc.  and Interactive Communication Services, Inc.
Description: Vending Communications, Inc., Interactive Communication Services, Inc., and their president agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they misrepresented the earnings that prospective purchasers of their business opportunities could realize.

The Federal Trade Commission, with the assistance of the U.S. Department of Justice, settled a complaint against a Massachusetts-based home security company that illegally called millions of consumers on the FTC's National Do Not Call (DNC) Registry to pitch home security systems.

Viatek Consumer Products Group, Inc. and company owner and President Lou Lentine agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they made deceptive claims for Viatek-brand Mosquito Shield Bands. The Commission also charged Lentine and Viatek with violating a 2003 administrative order prohibiting Lentine from making product claims without competent and reliable evidence to back them up.

A U.S. District Court ordered the operators of several international tech support scams to pay more than $5.1 million, acting on Federal Trade Commission charges that they masqueraded as major computer companies, tricked consumers into believing their computers were riddled with malware and then charged consumers to fix them.

Two authorized dealers of the satellite television provider Dish Network agreed to settle charges that they violated the FTC's Telemarketing Sales Rule by calling consumers whose numbers are on the Do Not Call Registry.

Company: Visions Group of America, Inc. and SOHO Technologies, Inc.
Description: Two companies and their principals that the Federal Trade Commission alleged used high-pressure sales tactics to sell various home-based business opportunities agreed to settle FTC accusations that they made false and unsubstantiated earnings claims to entice consumers to buy their products and violated the FTC's Cooling-Off Rule, which gives consumers three days to cancel certain purchases of $25 or more.

Two Maine-based dietary supplement marketers and their principals have agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they made deceptive advertising claims about their dietary supplement products, in violation of federal law.

Marketers of Focus Factor, a dietary supplement that purported to improve concentration, and V-Factor, a supplement that purported to enhance sexual performance, agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they made numerous unsubstantiated advertising claims for the products.

VIZIO, Inc., one of the Largest manufacturers and sellers of internet-connected smart televisions, agreed to pay $2.2 million to allegations by the Federal Trade Commission and the Office of the New Jersey Attorney General that it installed software on its TVs to collect viewing data on 11 million consumer TVs without consumers' knowledge or consent.

Vocational Guides, Inc. and its president were permanently banned from promoting or selling employment services, and were required to pay approximately $191,600 in disgorgement and consumer redress as part of a settlement of Federal Trade Commission allegations that they engaged in the fraudulent sale of employment services.

The Federal Trade Commission announced a complaint and proposed consent decree settling charges that a California-based voice broadcaster made over 46 million unlawful telemarketing calls. The proposed court order permanently barred the defendants from violating the FTC's Telemarketing Sales Rule and required them to pay $180,000 in civil penalties.

A deceptive robocall operation that allegedly used millions of pre-recorded telemarketing messages to fraudulently pitch extended auto warranties to U.S. consumers agreed to pay more than $655,000 in consumer redress and were permanently banned from telemarketing, as part of a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission.

Company: W3 Innovations, LLC dba Broken Thumbs Apps
Description: A developer of mobile applications, including children's games for the iPhone and iPod touch, agreed to pay $50,000 to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) and the FTC's COPPA Rule by illegally collecting and disclosing personal information from tens of thousands of children under age 13 without their parents' prior consent.

Following a public comment period, the Federal Trade Commission has approved two final orders settling charges that two companies, Norm Thompson Outfitters. Inc., and Wacoal America, Inc., misled consumers regarding the ability of their caffeine-infused shapewear undergarments to reshape the wearer's body and reduce cellulite.

National pharmacy chain Walgreens agreed to pay nearly $6 million to settle FTC charges that the company deceptively advertised Wal-Born, a line of dietary supplements similar to the Airborne cold-and-flu treatment,  using the same kind of baseless claims that the supplements could prevent colds, fight germs, and boost the immune system.

Company: We The People Forms and Service Centers USA, Inc.
Description: A company that sold legal document preparation franchises agreed to pay a $286,000 civil penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it violated federal law by failing to disclose lawsuits against it to prospective franchisees.

Operators who allegedly crammed unauthorized charges for website services onto the phone bills of hundreds of thousands of small businesses and non-profits agreed to pay more than $1.2 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that their operations violated federal law.

Weider Nutrition International, Inc., based in Salt Lake City, Utah, agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it made unsubstantiated efficacy and safety claims in its advertisements for dietary supplement products.

A federal court has found that marketers of bogus remedies for treating and preventing diabetes violated Section 5 of the FTC Act, and has ordered them to pay nearly $2.2 million. The FTC will use the funds it recovers to reimburse consumers.
A leading debt collection company agreed to pay a civil penalty of $2.8 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that its aggressive collection techniques violated federal law.

To settle Federal Trade Commission allegations, West Coast Advertising & Marketing and its principals agreed to pay $90,000 and verify the accuracy of claims they made on behalf of nonprofits for whom they solicited funds.

A debt collection agency that allegedly used lies and threats to collect debts agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that its tactics violated federal laws. Under the court settlement, the company agreed to a $150,000 judgment and to refrain from illegal practices when collecting debts, including time-barred debts -- debts so old they are no longer legally enforceable.

Educational services company WordSmart Corporation and its president agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they deceptively marketed the company's programs to the parents of school-age children in advertising that included a television infomercial featuring quiz show host Alex Trebek.

Company: World Interactive Gaming Corp. et al.
Description: Internet gambling casino developers charged with using deceptive claims to sell stock in their business agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that their practices violated federal laws.

World Wide Coffee, Inc., based in Jupiter, Florida, and its agreed to settle FTC allegations that they failed to provide the pre-sale disclosures to prospective purchasers of their espresso coffee machine vending opportunities.
Social networking website operator Xanga.com, Inc. and its principals agreed to pay a $1 million civil penalty for allegedly violating the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act.

Acting on a Federal Trade Commission complaint, a federal court has ordered a European-based operation to pay more than $10.2 million for tricking small businesses and nonprofit organizations into paying for unwanted listings in online business directories. The default judgment permanently bans the defendants from marketing Internet directories and listings in the future, and prohibits them from collecting payments from their previous customers, disclosing or otherwise benefitting from customers' personal information, and failing to dispose of this information properly.

Online review site Yelp, Inc., and mobile app developer TinyCo, Inc., agreed to settle separate Federal Trade Commission charges that they improperly collected children's information in violation of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, or COPPA, Rule. Under the terms of the settlements, Yelp will pay a $450,000 civil penalty, while TinyCo will pay a $300,000 civil penalty.
The FTC announced that Yesmail agreed to pay a $50,717 penalty to resolve a case involving the sending of unsolicited commercial e-mail after consumers asked it to stop.

At the request of the Federal Trade Commission, a federal court entered a judgment of more than $3.6 million against a payment processor and its subsidiary that allegedly debited consumers' bank accounts illegally on behalf of deceptive telemarketers. According to a 2007 complaint filed by the FTC and seven states, Your Money Access, LLC and its subsidiary, YMA Company, LLC, processed unauthorized debits on behalf of deceptive telemarketers and Internet-based schemes that were violating the FTC's Telemarketing Sales Rule and state consumer protection laws.

The Federal Trade Commission announced that two investment funds, ESL Partners, L.P. and ZAM Holdings, L.P., agreed to settle allegations that they violated federal law by failing to make timely filings with the government prior to acquiring blocks of AutoZone, Inc. shares in September and October of 2004.

Zango, Inc., formerly known as 180solutions, Inc., a large distributor of adware, and two principals agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they used unfair and deceptive methods to download adware and obstruct consumers from removing it, in violation of federal law. The settlement barred future downloads of Zango's adware without consumers' consent, required Zango to provide a way for consumers to remove the adware, and required the company to give up $3 million in ill-gotten gains.

A Southern California-based auto dealership group was required to pay $1.4 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it violated a 2014 administrative order prohibiting it from misrepresenting how much consumers could pay to finance or lease a vehicle.

An office supplier and its owner agreed to pay $7 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that they tricked child care centers, schools, and police and fire departments into paying for products they never ordered.

InfoCision, Inc., an Akron, Ohio-based company that has made millions of calls to consumers nationwide on behalf of charitable organizations, agreed to pay a $250,000 civil penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that its telemarketers misled consumers by falsely saying they were not calling to solicit contributions.

Description: Forms Direct, Inc., also known as American Immigration Center, agreed to pay $2.2 milllion in customer refunds to settle allegations that its webswite falsely implied an affiliation with the U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS).

RealPage agreed to pay $3 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that the company failed to take reasonable steps to ensure the accuracy of tenant screening information that it provided to landlords and property managers, a violation of federal law that caused some potential renters to be falsely associated with criminal records.
The order imposed a judgment of $12.8 million, which was to be suspended upon payment of $50,000 to the Commission and the payment of certain unpaid income tax obligations.

Avant LLC, an online lending company, agreed to pay $3.85 million to settle allegations that it engaged in deceptive and unfair loan servicing practices, such as imposing unauthorized charges on consumers' accounts and unlawfully requiring consumers to consent to automatic payments from their bank accounts.

A Georgia-based distributor of water filtration systems agreed to pay a $110,000 civil penalty to settle allegations that it violated a 2017 Federal Trade Commission administrative order by making false claims that wholly imported Chinese water filtration systems were made in the United States.

At the Federal Trade Commission's request, a U.S. district court judge imposed a $2.7 million judgement and permanently halted what the FTC called an office supply scam operated by a business known as A-1 Janitorial. In late 2017, the FTC charged the defendants with targeting small businesses and charging them for supposedly free samples of cleaning and other products.

Thomas Wells and his payment processing company, Priority Payout Corp., agreed to settle FTC charges that they repeatedly violated a 2009 court order issued against them. The settlement permanently banned Wells and Priority Payout Corp. from engaging in, and assisting others with, payment processing, and included a $1.8 million contempt judgment against them.

A federal judge ordered journal publisher and conference organizer Srinubabu Gedela and his companies to pay more than $50.1 million to resolve Federal Trade Commission allegations that they made deceptive claims to academics and researchers about the nature of their conferences and publications, and hid steep publication fees.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Office Depot merged with Office Max in 2013. In 2020 ODP Corporation was created as a holding company.
Description: Office Depot, Inc. and a California-based tech support software provider agreed to pay a total of $35 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that the companies tricked customers into buying millions of dollars' worth of computer repair and technical services by deceptively claiming their software had found malware symptoms on the customers' computers.

Office Depot, Inc. and a California-based tech support software provider agreed to pay a total of $35 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that the companies tricked customers into buying millions of dollars' worth of computer repair and technical services by deceptively claiming their software had found malware symptoms on the customers' computers.

Company: Perfect Image Online LLC, and Pinnacle Presence LLC

Recap of Ownership Changes: Career Education Corp. changed its name to Perdoceo Education Corp. in 2020.
Description: An Illinois-based operator of several post-secondary schools agreed to pay $30 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it used sales leads from lead generators that falsely told consumers they were affiliated with the U.S. militar, and that used other unlawful tactics to generate leads.

Equinox International and its owner agreed to hand over assets worth an estimated $40,0000 to eight states and the Federal Trade Commission as part of the resolution of allegations they engaged in an illegal pyramid scheme. The settlement was also announced by some of the states; see the separate Violation Tracker multistate entry.

Recap of Ownership Changes: In 2021 Facebook Inc. changed the name of its parent to Meta Platforms
Description: Facebook, Inc. agreed to pay a $5 billion penalty and submit to new restrictions and a modified corporate structure that will hold the company accountable for the decisions it makes about user privacy, to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that the company violated a 2012 order by deceiving users about their ability to control the privacy of their personal information.

Recap of Ownership Changes: Alphabet was created as a holding company for Google in 2015
Description: Google and YouTube agreed to pay $136 million to the FTC and  $34 million to New York State to settle allegations that the companies violated rules regarding the online collection of personal data on children.

Leasecomm agreed to cancel $24 million in judgments allegedly obtained through deception and agreed to reform all business opportunity financing contracts to settle allegations brought by the Federal Trade Commission and an eight-state task force. The settlement was also announced by some of the states; see the separate Violation Tracker multistate entry.

Reckitt Benckiser Group agreed to pay $50 million to settle allegations that it violated the antitrust laws through a deceptive scheme to thwart lower-priced generic competition to its branded drug Suboxone.

AT&T Mobility, LLC agreed to pay $60 million to settle litigation with the Federal Trade Commission over allegations that the wireless provider misled millions of its smartphone customers by charging them for unlimited data plans while reducing their data speeds.

NatureCity agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations it deceived consumers with false and unsupported claims that two products, TrueAloe and AloeCran, were effective treatments for a range of conditions affecting seniors, including chronic pain, ulcerative colitis, diabetes, and acid reflux.

Multi-level marketer AdvoCare International, L.P. and its former chief executive officer agreed to pay $150 million and be banned from the multi-level marketing business to resolve Federal Trade Commission charges that the company operated an illegal pyramid scheme that deceived consumers into believing they could earn significant income as distributors of its health and wellness products.

Under a proposed consent order, Belize's Atlantic International Bank Limited will pay $23 million, representing approximately all of its U.S.-based assets, to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it assisted various related entities in deceiving U.S. consumers as part of a scheme to sell property in Sanctuary Belize.

The University of Phoenix and its parent company, Apollo Education Group, agreed to pay a record $191 million -- $50 million in cash and $141 million in cancellation of student debt -- to resolve Federal Trade Commission charges that they used deceptive advertisements that falsely touted their relationships and job opportunities with companies such as AT&T, Yahoo!, Microsoft, Twitter, and The American Red Cross.

Kohl's Department Stores, Inc. agreed to pay a civil penalty of $220,000 to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that the Wisconsin-based retailer violated the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA) by refusing to provide complete records of transactions to consumers whose personal information was used by identity thieves.

One of the biggest payment processing companies and its former executive agreed to pay more than $40.2 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that they knowingly processed payments and laundered, or assisted laundering of, credit card transactions for scams that targeted hundreds of thousands of consumers.

Company: Position Gurus and Top Shelf Ecommerce

Description: laundering credit card payments

Online fashion retailer Fashion Nova will pay $9.3 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it didn't properly notify consumers and give them the chance to cancel their orders when it failed to ship merchandise in a timely manner, and that it illegally used gift cards to compensate consumers for unshipped merchandise instead of providing refunds.

Progressive Leasing, a company that markets rent-to-own payment plans in tens of thousands of retail stores nationwide, will pay $175 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it misled consumers about the true price of items purchased through its plans.

Home products and kitchen wares company Williams-Sonoma Inc. agreed to stop making false, misleading, or unsubstantiated claims that all of its Goldtouch Bakeware products, its Rejuvenation-branded products, and Pottery Barn Teen and Pottery Barn Kids-branded upholstered furniture products are all or virtually all made in the United States.

Impetus Enterprise, Inc. and Fig Tree & Co., LLC
Age of Learning, Inc. dba ABCmouse
Description: Online children's education company Age of Learning, Inc., which operates ABCmouse, agreed to pay $10 million and change its negative option marketing and billing practices to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it made misrepresentations about cancellations and failed to disclose important information to consumers, leading tens of thousands of people to be renewed and charged for memberships without proper consent.

Indivior, Inc. agreed to pay $10 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that it violated antitrust laws through a deceptive scheme to thwart lower priced generic competition with its branded opioid replacement therapy drug Suboxone.

Williams-Sonoma agreed to pay $1 million to settle allegations that it made false, misleading, or unsubstantiated claims that all of its Goldtouch Bakeware products, its Rejuvenation-branded products, and Pottery Barn Teen and Pottery Barn Kids-branded upholstered furniture products were all or virtually all made in the United States.

Retail fuel station and convenience store operator Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc.  and its former affiliate, CrossAmerica Partners LP agreed to pay a $3.5 million civil penalty to the FTC to settle allegations that they violated a 2018 order requiring divestitures of 10 retail fuel stations in Minnesota and Wisconsin to Commission-approved buyers no later than June 15, 2018.

Company: Seed Consulting LLC and Credit Navigator LLC

Description: deceptive Made in USA claim

A California-based company that provides background reports to property management companies will pay $4.25 million as part of a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission over allegations the firm failed to follow reasonable procedures to ensure the accuracy of its reports about potential tenants.

BASF SE, its subsidiary, BASF Corp. and DIEM Labs together agreed to pay more than $416,000 to settle charges that they deceptively marketed two dietary fish oil supplements as clinically proven to reduce liver fat in adults and children with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

Smart home security and monitoring company Vivint Smart Homes Inc. agreed to pay $20 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that the Utah-based firm misused credit reports to help unqualified customers obtain financing for the company's products and services.

Yellowstone Capital, a provider of merchant cash advances, agreed to pay more than $9.8 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it took money from businesses' bank accounts without permission and deceived them about the amount of financing business owners would receive and other features of its financing products.

Online lender LendingClub Corporation agreed to pay $18 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that the company deceived consumers about hidden fees that it charged and about whether their loan applications were approved.

Following a public comment period, the Federal Trade Commission has approved a final administrative consent order against Amazon, which has agreed to pay more than $61.7 million to settle charges that it failed to pay Amazon Flex drivers the full amount of tips they received from Amazon customers over a two and a half year period.

The Federal Trade Commission and a group of state attorneys general announced an agreement that will end the illegal and monopolistic behavior of Vyera Pharmaceuticals LLC -- previously known as Turing Pharmaceuticals -- and its former CEO. The agreement also forces Vyera and its parent company, Phoenixus AG, to pay up to $40 million and bans Mulleady from having almost any role with a pharmaceutical company for seven years.

The Federal Trade Commission obtained an order permanently banning a payment processor that facilitated a fraudulent student loan debt relief scheme from processing debt relief payments. The order also requires the company and its owner to surrender $500,000 to the FTC for consumer redress.
An Atlanta-based debt collection company and its owners will be permanently banned from the debt collection industry under the terms of a settlement with the Federal Trade Commission.

California-based online advertising platform OpenX Technologies, Inc. will be required to pay $2 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that the company collected personal information from children under 13 without parental consent, a direct violation of a federal children's privacy protection law.

MyLife.com, Inc. and its CEO were banned from engaging in deceptive negative option marketing and will pay $21 million following allegations that they tricked consumers with teaser background reports and trapped them in difficult-to-cancel subscription programs.

The Federal Trade Commission announced that restaurant chain owner and investment fund operator Biglari Holdings Inc. will pay a $1.4 million civil penalty to settle charges that two acquisitions it made on March 26, 2020 of shares of restaurant operator Cracker Barrel Old Country Store, Inc. violated the Hart-Scott-Rodino Act.

Online fashion retailer Fashion Nova, LLC will be prohibited from suppressing customer reviews of its products and required to pay $4.2 million to settle Federal Trade Commission allegations that the company blocked negative reviews of its products from being posted to its website.

New York City-based Vision Path, Inc., the online seller of direct-to-consumer Hubble lenses, will pay penalties and redress totaling $3.5 million to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it violated the Contact Lens Rule in several ways, including by failing to obtain prescriptions and to properly verify prescription information, and by substituting Hubble lenses for those actually prescribed to consumers.

The Federal Trade Commission's lawsuit against RCG Advances, LLC led to acourt orderthat permanently bans the company from the merchant cash advance industry for deceiving and threatening small businesses and their owners. The FTC alleged that the scheme's operators lied to small business owners about terms and fees for their financing, and threatened them with violence when they were unable to pay. In addition, the court ordered RCG Advances and Giardina to make an upfront payment of $1.5 million and subsequent payment of more than $1.2 million to refund consumers.

The Federal Trade Commission took action against R360 LLC and its owner for deceiving people seeking help for addiction about the evaluation and selection criteria for the treatment centers in their network.

The Federal Trade Commission took action againstapparel company Lions Not Sheep Products LLC and its owner for falsely claiming that its imported apparel is Made in USA. According to the FTC's complaint, the company added phony Made in USA labels to clothing and accessories imported from China and other countries. The FTC's proposed order requires Lions Not Sheep and Whalen to stop making bogus Made in USA claims, come clean about foreign production, and pay a monetary judgment.

In a case brought by the FTC and two California District Attorney offices, Frontier was fined $8.5 million and was required to spend an estimated $60 million to upgrade its fiber-optic DSL service, which was alleged to be much slower than advertised. The case was also announced by the DAs (see separate entry).
Warrior Tradingwas required to pay $3 millionto refund consumers and will be prohibited from making baseless claims about the potential for consumers to earn money using its trading strategies.

The Federal Trade Commission took action against a for-profit medical school in the Caribbean and its Illinois-based operators, alleging they deceptively marketed the school's medical license exam test pass rate and residency matches to lure prospective students.The $1.2 million judgment against Saint James School of Medicine and its operators will go toward refunds and debt cancellation for students harmed by the deceptive marketing.

Using its authority under theMade in USA Labeling Rule, which took effect in 2021, the FTC fined Lithionics Battery LLC$100,000 for illegally misrepresenting that its lithium ion cells are made in the United States.
Kohl's was fined $2.5 million for making deceptive environmental claims in marketing rayon products as bamboo.
Walmart was fined $3 million for making deceptive environmental claims in marketing rayon products as bamboo.

The Federal Trade Commission's trial win against On Point Global made $102 million in refunds available to consumers who were harmed by a wide-ranging scheme that led them to pay money or hand over personal information to fake government websites.

North American Automotive Services Inc., aka Edward Napleton Automotive Group agreed to pay $10 million to resolve allegations by the FTC and the State of Illinois that dealerships charged charged consumers for unwanted add-ons, discriminated against Black customers by charging more for financing, and violated Illinois motor vehicle advertising regulations by including coupons and offers of free gifts in its advertisements. The case was also announced by Illinois (see separate entry).

A payment processing company that allegedly helped a bogus discount club scheme debit tens of millions of dollars from consumers without authorization will berequired to pay$2.3 million and face a permanent ban from working with high-risk clients as a result of a Federal Trade Commission lawsuit.

The operators of RagingBull.com, an online stock trading site that used bogus earnings claims to trick consumers into signing up for services and then trapped them into hard-to-cancel subscription plans with costly charges,will be required to pay $2.425 million, end the earnings deception, get affirmative approval from consumers for subscription sign ups, and provide them with a simple method to cancel recurring charges.

WW International, Inc., formerly known as Weight Watchers, and a subsidiary called Kurbo, Inc. agreed to pay $1.5 million to settle allegations they marketed a weight loss app for use by children as young as eight and then collected their personal information without parental permission. The settlement order requires WW International and Kurbo to delete personal information illegally collected from children under 13 and destroy any algorithms derived from the data.

A marketer of teas and skincare products agreed to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it promoted its products using deceptive health claims and endorsements by well-known social media influencers who did not adequately disclose that they were being paid to promote its products. The order imposed a $15.2 million judgment--the total sales of the challenged products--which will be suspended upon payment of $1 million, based on the defendants' inability to pay the full judgment.

The Federal Trade Commissiontook actionagainst credit services company Credit Karma for misleading to think they were pre-approved for credit card offers for which they did not qualify. Theagency's orderrequired the company to pay $3 million to consumers who applied for the credit cards and to stop making the deceptive claims.

The Federal Trade Commission took action against healthcare company Benefytt Technologies, two subsidiaries, and two individuals for lying to consumers about their sham health insurance plans and using deceptive lead generation websites to lure them in. According to the FTC, Benefytt also illegally charged people exorbitant junk fees for unwanted add-on products without their permission. Benefytt agreed to pay $100 million in refunds and prohibit the company from lying about their products or charging illegal junk fees.

The Federal Trade Commission took action against online home buying firm Opendoor Labs Inc., for cheating potential home sellers by tricking them into thinking that they could make more money selling their home to Opendoor than on the open market using the traditional sales process.

The Federal Trade Commissiontook action against payment processing companyFirst American Payment Systems and two of its sales affiliates for trapping small businesses with hidden terms, surprise exit fees, and zombie charges.
